sn35.246:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rañño vā rājamahāmattassa vā vīṇāya saddo assutapubbo assa.
sn35.246:4.1.en: Suppose a king or their chief minister had never heard the sound of an arched harp.

sn35.246:4.6.pli: ‘esā, kho, bhante, vīṇā nāma, yassā eso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo evambandhanīyo’ti.

sn35.246:4.8.en: ‘Go, my man, fetch me that arched harp.’

sn35.246:4.11.pli: ‘ayaṁ kho sā, bhante, vīṇā yassā eso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo evambandhanīyo’ti.

sn35.246:4.13.pli: ‘alaṁ me, bho, tāya vīṇāya, tameva me saddaṁ āharathā’ti.
sn35.246:4.13.en: ‘I’ve had enough of that arched harp! Just fetch me the sound.’

sn35.246:4.15.pli: ‘ayaṁ kho, bhante, vīṇā nāma anekasambhārā mahāsambhārā.
sn35.246:4.15.en: ‘Sir, this arched harp is made of many components assembled together,

sn35.246:4.17.pli: doṇiñca paṭicca cammañca paṭicca daṇḍañca paṭicca upadhāraṇe ca paṭicca tantiyo ca paṭicca koṇañca paṭicca purisassa ca tajjaṁ vāyāmaṁ paṭicca evāyaṁ, bhante, vīṇā nāma anekasambhārā mahāsambhārā.
sn35.246:4.17.en: it depends on the body, the skin, the neck, the head, the strings, the plectrum, and a person to play it properly. That’s how an arched harp is made of many components assembled together,

sn35.246:4.19.pli: So taṁ vīṇaṁ dasadhā vā satadhā vā phāleyya, dasadhā vā satadhā vā taṁ phāletvā sakalikaṁ sakalikaṁ kareyya.
sn35.246:4.19.en: But he’d split that harp into ten pieces or a hundred pieces, then splinter it up.

sn35.246:4.23.pli: ‘asatī kirāyaṁ, bho, vīṇā nāma, yathevaṁ yaṁ kiñci vīṇā nāma ettha ca panāyaṁ jano ativelaṁ pamatto palaḷito’ti.
sn35.246:4.23.en: ‘It seems that there’s nothing to this thing called an arched harp or whatever’s called an arched harp! But people waste their time with it, negligent and heedless!’

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 35.246
19. The Simile of the Vipers
The Simile of the Harp

an6.55:4.2.pli: kusalo tvaṁ pubbe agāriyabhūto vīṇāya tantissare”ti?
an6.55:4.2.en: When you were still a layman, weren’t you a good player of the arched harp?”

an6.55:4.4.pli: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, soṇa, yadā te vīṇāya tantiyo accāyatā honti, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṁ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vā”ti?
an6.55:4.4.en: “When your harp’s strings were tuned too tight, was it resonant and playable?”

an6.55:5.1.pli: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, soṇa, yadā te vīṇāya tantiyo atisithilā honti, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṁ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vā”ti?
an6.55:5.1.en: “When your harp’s strings were tuned too slack, was it resonant and playable?”

an6.55:6.1.pli: “Yadā pana te, soṇa, vīṇāya tantiyo na accāyatā honti nātisithilā same guṇe patiṭṭhitā, api nu te vīṇā tasmiṁ samaye saravatī vā hoti kammaññā vā”ti?
an6.55:6.1.en: “But when your harp’s strings were tuned neither too tight nor too slack, but fixed at an even tension, was it resonant and playable?”

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 6.55
6. The Great Chapter
With Soṇa

dn21:1.2.4.pli: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya sakkassa devānamindassa anucariyaṁ upāgami.
dn21:1.2.4.en: “Yes, lord,” replied the centaur Pañcasikha. Taking his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood-apple, he went as Sakka’s attendant.

dn21:1.4.4.pli: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya yena indasālaguhā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā:
dn21:1.4.4.en: “Yes, lord,” replied the centaur Pañcasikha. Taking his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood-apple, he went to Indra’s hill cave. When he had drawn near, he stood to one side, thinking,

dn21:1.4.8.pli: Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ assāvesi, imā ca gāthā abhāsi buddhūpasañhitā dhammūpasañhitā saṅghūpasañhitā arahantūpasañhitā kāmūpasañhitā:
dn21:1.4.8.en: Standing to one side, Pañcasikha played his arched harp, and sang these verses on the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the perfected ones, and sensual love.

dn21:1.6.10.pli: Athāhaṁ beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya yena timbaruno gandhabbarañño nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ assāvesiṁ, imā ca gāthā abhāsiṁ buddhūpasañhitā dhammūpasañhitā saṅghūpasañhitā arahantūpasañhitā kāmūpasañhitā—
dn21:1.6.10.en: I took my arched harp to Timbaru’s home, where I played those verses.

sn17.3:1.7.en: and a hunter pierced her with a harpoon.

sn17.3:2.2.en: ‘Harpoon’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.

sn17.3:2.4.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṁ lābhasakkārasilokaṁ assādeti nikāmeti—
sn17.3:2.4.en: Whoever enjoys and likes arisen possessions, honor, and popularity is called a mendicant who has been pierced with a harpoon. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 17.3
Chapter One
A Turtle

sn4.23:10.7.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.23:10.7.en: Then Māra, carrying his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood apple, went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.23:14.2.en: that his harp dropped from his armpit,

thag7.2:2.2.en: in arched harps, and in cymbals.

mlDocs.title:
Verses of the Senior Monks 7.2
The Book of the Sevens
Chapter One
Bhaddiya the Dwarf

an6.30:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco bherisaddampi savanāya gacchati, vīṇāsaddampi savanāya gacchati, gītasaddampi savanāya gacchati, uccāvacaṁ vā pana savanāya gacchati, samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā micchādiṭṭhikassa micchāpaṭipannassa dhammassavanāya gacchati.
an6.30:3.2.en: Some people go to hear the sound of drums, arched harps, singing, or a diverse spectrum of sounds; or ascetics and brahmins of wrong view and wrong practice.

thag13.1:7.3.en: created the simile of the arched harp for me.

mlDocs.title:
Verses of the Senior Monks 13.1
The Book of the Thirteens
Chapter One
Soṇakoḷivisa

snp3.2:25.2.en: that his harp dropped from his armpit,

dn17:1.3.11.pli: hatthisaddena assasaddena rathasaddena bherisaddena mudiṅgasaddena vīṇāsaddena gītasaddena saṅkhasaddena sammasaddena pāṇitāḷasaddena ‘asnātha pivatha khādathā’ti dasamena saddena.
dn17:1.3.11.en: the sound of elephants, horses, chariots, drums, clay drums, arched harps, singing, horns, gongs, and handbells; and the cry, ‘Eat, drink, be merry!’ as the tenth.

dn16:5.18.8.pli: hatthisaddena assasaddena rathasaddena bherisaddena mudiṅgasaddena vīṇāsaddena gītasaddena saṅkhasaddena sammasaddena pāṇitāḷasaddena ‘asnātha pivatha khādathā’ti dasamena saddena.
dn16:5.18.8.en: the sound of elephants, horses, chariots, drums, clay drums, arched harps, singing, horns, gongs, and handbells; and the cry: ‘Eat, drink, be merry!’ as the tenth.

The Great Discourse on the Buddha’s Extinguishment
